contentrichtext.text: {{no footnotes|date=March 2013}} ''For others of this name see [[Archagathus (disambiguation)]]'' '''Caecilius''', of [[Calacte]] in [[Sicily]], Greek [[rhetoric]]ian, flourished at [[Rome]] during the reign of [[Augustus]]. Originally called '''Archagathus''', he took the name of Caecilius from his patron, one of the Metelli. According to the ''[[Suda]]'', he was of the [[Judaism|Jewish faith]]. Next to [[Dionysius Halicarnassensis|Dionysius of Halicarnassus]], he was the most important critic and rhetorician of the Augustan age. Only fragments are extant of his numerous and important works, among which may be mentioned: *''On the Style of the Ten Orators'' (the lives and a critical examination of the works of the [[Ten Orators]]), the basis of the pseudo-[[Plutarch]]ian treatise of the same name, in which Caecilius is frequently referred to; *''On the Sublime'', attacked by (?) [[Longinus (literature)|Longinus]] in his essay on the same subject; *''History of the Servile Wars'', or slave risings in Sicily, the local interest of which would naturally appeal to the author; *''On Rhetoric and Rhetorical Figures'', an ''Alphabetical Selection of Phrases'', intended to serve as a guide to the acquirement of a pure Attic style—the first example of an Atticist lexicon, mentioned by Suidas in the preface to his lexicon as one of his authorities; *''Against the Phrygians'', probably an attack on the florid style of the [[Asiatic school]] of rhetoric. ==References== *{{1911}} *[http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9018507/Caecilius-Of-Calacte Encyclopaedia Britannica Caecilius Of Calacte] *{{Citation |first=W. Rhys |last=Roberts |title=Caecilius of Calacte |journal=American Journal of Philology |volume=18 |issue=3 |year=1897 |pages=302–312 |doi=10.2307/287826 }}.
